articles.headline: United Methodist Church Reverses Ban on Practicing Gay Clergy
articles.snippet: In a meeting on Wednesday, church leaders also voted to allow L.G.B.T.Q. weddings.
articles.abstract: In a meeting on Wednesday, church leaders also voted to allow L.G.B.T.Q. weddings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Methodist Church removed on Wednesday its longstanding ban on ordaining gay clergy, formalizing a shift in policy that had already begun in practice and that had prompted the departure of a quarter of its U.S. congregations in recent years.

articles.headline: Blinken Turns Up Pressure on Hamas to Accept Gaza Cease-Fire Deal
articles.snippet: “The time is now,” Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken declared, urging Hamas to accept the terms of a proposed truce. He also made clear that he expected more from Israel.
articles.abstract: “The time is now,” Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken declared, urging Hamas to accept the terms of a proposed truce. He also made clear that he expected more from Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken delivered twin messages to Hamas and Israel on Wednesday, pressing Hamas to accept a cease-fire proposal while at the same time urging Israeli leaders to put off a major ground invasion into the thickly populated southern Gaza city of Rafah.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: U.S. and Israel Struggle With Clashing Visions on Ending Gaza War
articles.snippet: The Biden administration wants to focus on a cease-fire and rebuilding Gaza, but Israel’s leader is pushing a new offensive.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration wants to focus on a cease-fire and rebuilding Gaza, but Israel’s leader is pushing a new offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearing the end of a whirlwind Middle East trip this week, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken finished meetings with the Israeli president and relatives of American hostages held by Hamas, left his beachside hotel in Tel Aviv and shook hands with protesters gathered outside.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: The Judge Deciding Google’s Fate
articles.snippet: Amit P. Mehta, a judge in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, will issue a landmark antitrust ruling.
articles.abstract: Amit P. Mehta, a judge in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, will issue a landmark antitrust ruling.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Amit P. Mehta’s first cases after becoming a federal judge in late 2014 proved to be a crash course in antitrust.

articles.headline: They Used to Award Olympic Medals for Art?
articles.snippet: The founder of the modern Games thought they should honor both body and mind. But the tradition died years ago, and the winning artworks are largely forgotten.
articles.abstract: The founder of the modern Games thought they should honor both body and mind. But the tradition died years ago, and the winning artworks are largely forgotten.
articles.lead_paragraph: During all of the years that the Olympics gave out medals in arts, not just athletics — and if you didn’t know about that, the rest of this article may hold more surprises — the pinnacle came in Paris, 100 years ago this summer.

articles.headline: Joe Biden, the Ultimate D.C. Veteran, Has Never Seen a Campaign Like This
articles.snippet: In 30 years of Senate bids, Mr. Biden was such a formidable incumbent that he did not face a serious threat to his return to office. His last re-election is shaping up to be something different: a fight.
articles.abstract: In 30 years of Senate bids, Mr. Biden was such a formidable incumbent that he did not face a serious threat to his return to office. His last re-election is shaping up to be something different: a fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: In October 1984, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware was invited to address a conservative Baptist church near Wilmington as he campaigned for a third term.

articles.headline: Strongest U.S. Challenge to Big Tech’s Power Nears Climax in Google Trial
articles.snippet: The first tech monopoly trial of the modern internet era is concluding. The judge’s ruling is likely to set a precedent for other attempts to rein in the tech giants that hold sway over information, social interaction and commerce.
articles.abstract: The first tech monopoly trial of the modern internet era is concluding. The judge’s ruling is likely to set a precedent for other attempts to rein in the tech giants that hold sway over information, social interaction and commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest U.S. challenge so far to the vast power of today’s tech giants is nearing its conclusion.

articles.headline: As Kentucky Derby Nears, Last Year’s Deaths Cast Long Shadow
articles.snippet: The breakdown of 12 horses in the days surrounding the celebrated race a year ago has led to existential questions about the sport and its future.
articles.abstract: The breakdown of 12 horses in the days surrounding the celebrated race a year ago has led to existential questions about the sport and its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Derby has been run through two World Wars, the Great Depression, civil rights unrest and, most recently, a life-paralyzing pandemic. Now, on the 150th anniversary of America’s most famous race, the Sport of Kings faces another formidable foe: itself.
articles.byline: By Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert

articles.headline: Signs of Brain Injury in Mortar Soldiers: ‘Guys Are Getting Destroyed’
articles.snippet: Soldiers exposed to thousands of low-level blasts from firing weapons like mortars say that they wind up with debilitating symptoms of traumatic brain injury — but no diagnosis.
articles.abstract: Soldiers exposed to thousands of low-level blasts from firing weapons like mortars say that they wind up with debilitating symptoms of traumatic brain injury — but no diagnosis.
articles.lead_paragraph: After firing about 10,000 mortar rounds during four years of training, one soldier who joined the Army with near-perfect scores on the military aptitude test was struggling to read or do basic math.

articles.headline: Can a ‘Not Charlotte’ Recipe Revive a Region?
articles.snippet: North Carolina’s Triad was built on tobacco, textiles and furniture. Now it’s trying to forge a new economy from more highly skilled manufacturing.
articles.abstract: North Carolina’s Triad was built on tobacco, textiles and furniture. Now it’s trying to forge a new economy from more highly skilled manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scott Kidd didn’t expect a terribly busy job when he became the town manager of Liberty, N.C., a onetime furniture and textile hub whose rhythms more recently centered on a yearly antiques festival.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar and Mike Belleme

articles.headline: Biden Denounces Violence on Campus, Breaking Silence After Rash of Arrests
articles.snippet: President Biden defended the right to dissent but made clear that he believed too many of the demonstrations had gone beyond the bounds of free speech.
articles.abstract: President Biden defended the right to dissent but made clear that he believed too many of the demonstrations had gone beyond the bounds of free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden broke days of silence on Thursday to finally speak out on the wave of protests on American college campuses against Israel’s war in Gaza that have inflamed much of the country, denouncing violence and antisemitism even as he defended the right to peaceful dissent.
